abstract.text: Automate scriptable apps by sending and receiving Apple events.
The
class provides a mechanism enabling an Objective-C
program to send Apple events to a scriptable application and receive Apple
events in response. It thereby makes it possible for that program to control
the application and exchange data with it. Scripting Bridge works by
bridging data types between Apple event descriptors and Cocoa objects.
The
class declares methods that can be invoked on any object in a
scriptable application. It defines methods for getting elements and
properties of an object, as well as setting a given object to a new value.
Returns an array containing every child of the receiver with the given
class-type code.
Forces evaluation of the receiver, causing the real object to be returned
immediately.
Initializes and returns an instance of an
subclass.
Returns an instance of an
subclass initialized with the given
data.
Returns an instance of an
subclass initialized with the specified
properties and data and added to the designated element array.
Returns an instance of an
subclass initialized with the specified
properties.
The error from the last event this object sent, or nil if it succeeded.
Returns an object of the designated scripting class representing the
specified property of the receiver
Returns an object representing the specified property of the receiver.
Sends an Apple event with the given event class, event ID, and format to the
target application.
Sets the receiver to a specified value.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
